awd_titl_txt: CIF - Small: High Resolution Computational Imaging with Motion in Spatially Varying Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
Basic questions about optical information in the presence of scatter, and more specifically, related to object motion in spatially varying electromagnetic fields, is being addressed. Light provides key information through spectroscopy, paramount in human health applications, and allows for high-resolution imaging. However, random optical scatter due to tissue, for example, can obfuscate an object of interest. Such random scatter produces speckle, the granular nature of light seen when a laser pointer scatters from a rough surface. A new computational imaging method is being developed to image hidden objects based on motion in such structured fields. With control over laser illumination and precise motion, far-subwavelength feature information can be obtained. This understanding is being developed into a high resolution computational imaging approach, critical in a variety of applications.

One aspect of this project involves the use of optical speckle correlations over object position or as a function of time for imaging through or within a heavily scattering medium at potentially wavelength scale resolution. The goal of this project is to take the initial presentation of this concept to a practical computational imaging modality. Measured laser speckle images with example scattering media, representative of several centimeters of tissue, are being used with various levels of understanding about the moving objects. The other direction is to develop a computational method to determine if a small object is present by precisely scanning a sample in a spatially varying field established by two or more laser beams. A key application is to determine whether a defect exists in a semiconductor material system. More generally, opportunities for far-subwavelength optical imaging based on motion in structured illumination is being pursued.

por.por_cntn:
During this project, we investigated mathematical and computational aspects of super-resolution imaging based on motion in structured illumination. Far-field imaging, optical storage, and lithography are limited in resolution to about one wavelength, implying that a reduction in wavelength, measurement in the near-field are necessary to increase resolution, or some form of constraint on the inversion is needed to obtain higher spatial resolution. With controlled motion of an object in a spatially varying electromagnetic field, such as can be achieved with interfering laser beams or speckled light due to random scatter, far-field measurements contain information about far-subwavelength geometrical information. The central goal of this project has been to develop a framework to image at high resolution using the concept of object motion in structured illumination.

We developed a general theory for coherent sensing of an object moving in a heavily scattering medium that leads to a method to image the object's macroscopic geometry. In this case, the object is moving in a speckled field and information is extracted from a statistical treatment of measured intensity correlations over object position. This theory also has a parameterization that is linked to far-subwavelength structural features, thereby forming a basis for super-resolution sensing and potentially imaging. Using phase retrieval, we demonstrated macroscopic imaging of complex structures that are translated between two heavily scattering domains, in transmission, and also in reflection, when the object was hidden behind a heavily scattering medium.

We presented super-resolution localization based on optical contrast, such as fluorescence, using a diffusion equation Green's function. This constraint based approach enables a variety of applications where multiply-scattered light is involved.

We demonstrated an ability to image a falling object through heavy fog using speckle correlations, with images taken as a function of time being converted to distance using Newtonian mechanics.

Imaging based on motion in a speckled field requires information on translation distance. One approach is to use localization within a diffusion framework to estimate the set of positions at which speckle data is collected, and the precision of this has been investigated. We have now demonstrated speckle imaging based on position information from localization data.

New experiments with an object hidden between two heavily scattering slabs and with motion over the length scale of just a few wavelengths support the availability of microstructure information. We are now pursuing a numerical study to develop understanding of the relationship between the nanostructured material and the short-range speckle decorrelation.

We presented the concept of a random analyzer placed in front of a camera as a means to enhance the spatial resolution with coherent optical sensing, based on motion in a structured incident field, and demonstrated the effect through experiments. We have developed a theory and obtained numerical simulations that support the concept, and both have provided deeper understanding.

Motion of a 1D object (a film on a substrate to be characterized) in a standing wave field with a forward electromagnetic model describing the scatter of light as a function of translated position is presented as a means to characterize the parameters associated with this film. This approach should provide an improvement over solid state film characterization using ellipsometry.

We presented motion in a structured field as a new method to obtain super resolution. An alternative, where the field is scanned over a stationary object with far-field intensity measurements, has been investigated through a series of simulations that indicate this as an effective approach. Such beam control can be implemented in a variety of ways and could allow rapid measurements.

We developed a learning module (Magic of Math) for Math 7 students with four components. This will be presented to West Lafayette junior high school students.
